Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) = \\int_0^t e^{sA} x(s) ds \\) where \\( x(s) \\) is a time-dependent input vector and A is a constant matrix. We explore the impact of introducing a transformation \\( h(x) = e^{Bt}x \\) over time t, where B is also a constant matrix.

If \\( h(x) \\) is applied to \\( x(s) \\) before computing \\( z(t) \\), will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if no transformation was applied to the inputs \\( x(s) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( h(x) \\) modifies \\( x(s) \\) by multiplying it with \\( e^{Bs} \\) at each instant s. This affects the integral computation by altering both the magnitude and orientation of the input within the integral. The result is a different \\( z(T) \\), as the dynamics introduced by B have a compounded effect over time on \\( x(s) \\) before they are integrated.
